editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

Full documentation of the original data capture process is available from the Text Creation Partnership web site. All versions of the texts are now archived and freely available for download. See the TCP Download FAQ for detailed information. The TEI P5 versions are also freely available from the TCP Github repository.

div.p: A NEW Creed.
Consisting of XII. ARTICLES for every true Protestant and Loyall Subject within the three Kingdomes of England, Scotland and Ireland to make Profession of.
In manner and forme following.
Printed 1648.

div.head: ARTICLE. I.
div.p: I Doe be • eeve King CHARLES to be my undoubted Soveraigne, and that by hereditary succession, the three Crownes of England, Scotland, and Ireland are by proper right entail'd on y upon him and his Posterity, and that no sub • unary Power, by what law, pretence, interest, clame or title soever can divest him of any part of that right power, authority, and honour naturally annexed to his Royall Person, without violation of the Lawes of Nature, Reason, Con • cience & Religion; withou the extirpation of the Nationall and sundamentall Lawes (an act of highest treason) being the onely ligaments, and sinnewes of this Kingdome; and the most horrid breach of Protestations, Oaths and Covenants; and that no person or persons, of what degree or quality soever, m • y encroach upon him, or any thing duely appertaining to him, without incurring for every • uch act or acts, a just censure and conv • ction of Theft, Treason, and Rebellion.

Second y, I doe be • eeve K • ng CHARLES to have more grace in his hear, and more Wit in his litt • e fing • r, then the • e is in all the hearts, and the whole body of the Par • iament now sitting at Westminster; and though just J • alousies and Fe • t •
made him to desert his Parliament, yet I beleeve they could never make him decline his Principles; and I doe confidently presume that that Dagon to which the Goliahs and Philistins of this Kingdom have these seven yeers fall'n down and worship't, will ere long doe homage to that Royall Arke (Mercy-seat, and our Israels glory, canopi'd with Cherubims wings) in a headlesse tribute, too slight a recompence for treason and Idolatry.

Thirdly I doe beleeve, that King CHARLES hath suffered more then any Prince since the land was first a Monarchy, and though his enemies have conquered his Person, yet his Spirit is invincible; so that though over-com'd, he still remaines a Conquerer. I beleeve he needed no other honour to his combates, but the equity of his quarrell, and the goodnesse of his cause; which though the dull-ey'd Multitude could not then behold; yet now they have got Spectacles, they discerne him (though at a distance yet) triumphing in a bloodlesse victory.

div.head: ART. II.
div.p: I doe beleeue, That those whom God hath joyn'd together, no man ought to separate, and that Queen MARY the lawfull Spouse of our dread Soveraigne, being unlawfully banished & disserted from the comfortable fruition of her Royall Consort, is flat opposition to the Lawes of God, and consequently rebellion against God himself, & that the Parliament have endeavoured as much as in them lyeth, of an honest and vertuous woman, to make her an arrant whore; who but Parliament men would doe such things? moreover I beleeve that to expell Papacy, which is but one faction, and entertaine, and encourage many, to drive out Episcopacie, and bring in liberty, to pu • l downe Monarchy, and set up Aristocracie, is the evidence of self-ends, hypocriticall, Diabolicall.

div.head: ART. III.
div.p: I beleeve, That the Parliament conven'd by Royall authority. Anno 1640. was a lawfull and con • ciencious Parliament; and I doe beleeve that when the whole body thereof is aptly and compleatly unite together in the Members, without any forcible dislocation, or false election, it is then the highest Judicatory in this Kingdome; but to say that the Parliament (statu quo nunc.) being disjoynted, severed and mangled in its members, (scarce one third part appearing) and acting by a self-seeking gladiatory and tyrannicall Power, is a lawfull and an equall Parliament; J confesse J have not so much faith as to beleve it; much lesse to thinke that they have any power obligatory to binde the Conscience of any Subject to yeeld either active or passive obedience, to any Act or Ordinance from them proceeding, being a meer compound of usurpation, illegally sitting, and as illegally acting, conerary to Parliamentary power, and not as the visible Representatives of the body po • itiqe.

Secondly J beleeve, That illegall Conventicle of men in the Parliament House, to be the onely Authors and fomentors of these unnaturall and civill Warres and Devisions; and guilty of all the innocent blood that hath been shed within this Kingdome; and that they striue to hold up their most intollerable tyranny, though with the losse of Three Kingdomes, as appears by their disrespects of poor death-sick Jreland, their • lownesse in answering the Demands of Scotland, and their unconscionable and refractory Propositions to his Majestie, • ending as much to the publique Peace, as Edge-hill fight, or the murder of his Royall Person.

Thirdly J beleeve, That if this Parliament were once off of the hooks or throwne out of the Kingdoms saddle, (who have so long rid Hackney, till they have broke the backs of the
whole tribe of Issachar, and the Manie-asses of this Nation) and another Parliament chosen, of men whose fingers never d • opt with blood, certain • y our Peace • ies before us, and all our grievances were at a period; (for it is impossib • e th • t the sweet sounds of Peace and joy should be heard within out walls, so long as the • e men of b ood sit pearch't abo • e us with the sword in one hand, and the Scepter in another:) provided that his Majesties Power and Rega • l Priviledge be no wayes infring'd; but that he with them may • ettle a l things into order, (the whee • es o • the S • ate being broken by these Egyptian Charetors) so sha • l thi • poo • languish • ng Kingdome yet live to be the envie and the g • ory of the wor • d.

div.head: ART. IV.
div.p: I belee • e, that thing which they call a Synod to be a thing of nothing; a company of slow pac'd Dromedaries, not good for any thing except the • are name of an Assembly, who have so long been b • under • ng upon the Artic • es of Faith, that they have qui • e lost their credit; and I be • eeve, if their buttocks did not grow by the • r tedious junctu • es to the benches whereon they sit; that shame or good manners had long since rouz'd them from their • quat, who now are growne a • shamelesse as they came brain • esse, having evacuated their profound witt • into their deeper pockets, made a • gally-maufrey of Religion, which before was pure and sound (not needing any of their compounded antidotes) and turn'd the Hou • e of God quite out of the Windowe • .

div.head: ART. V.
div.p:
I beleeve, That his Exce • lency hath yet some • ee •• of grace remain • ng in him, and that as he did well when h • was the King Subject, so he may now doe better to be the K • ngs servant; what though hither • o • ittle obedience is ob • e •• b • e? yet I wou • d have him know, that whi • st he g ••• s on hi • M • st • rs for remuneration of de •• rt, whi • st he acts fide • ity, to satisfie their ends, if he glance but on one side▪ t •• n he hath whet a sword to pr • me his own head; and before his wings are too
much entangled in these Parliament lime-twiggs, let him beware, least too late repentance (with many or his so exalted brethren) make him cry, Had-I-wist.

div.head: ART, VI.
div.p: I beleeve, the Army will now grow honest, the tares (the Agitators) being weeded up; and that there is no way for them to recover their Arears, but to joyne with his Majestie, who hath a • ready made a Royall Promise (beseeming such a King) whose Thought is his Word, his Word a Law, that Law unalterab • e; that he will performe the same.

Secondly I beleeve, That the Souldiers have more wit then to come into the City to exact or leavie their pay, their head-pieces scap'd a scouring at their first being there, it is a strong temptation to presume the second time.

div.head: ART. VII.
div.p: I beleeve, That the head of Anarchy is crusht into the very braines by the unanimity of the Army, and that though Consciences may be countenanced, yet Heresy, Schisme and Prophanes shall not be continued and authorized.

div.head: ART. VIII.
div.p: I beleeve, that the publike faith which lies now in Lavenddr for the Parliaments debts, is not worth a lowse, and all those that have lent out coyne upon such usury, shall ere long have it return'd to 'em by Tom Long the Carrier.

div.head: ART. IX.
div.p:
I beleeve, and am verily perswaded, That the time is at hand, when the Three Kingdomes shall be linck't together in one love-knot that his Majestie shall be set againe upon his Royal Throne (if a blow prevent not) and sway the scepter of his Kingdome in Peace; that Satans Synagogue at Westminster shall be turn'd into a holy Senate, and the Devill voted out of the Parliament-Hou • e, and then shall plenteousnesse walke in our streets, and our houses be filled with rejoycings; then shall
Cheap-side conduit run with wine, and both rich and poor drink a health, and cry, GOD save King CHARLES.

div.head: ART. X.
div.p: I beleeve, That if Peters and Dell, those infernall Regiclde • , that Rainsborow, Martyn, and Scot, the Agents and Agitators that have conspired against the Lords Anoynted, and the Peace and happinesse of the Kingdome; be not hang'd according to their deserts, that those Foxes with their fire-brands, will set the whole Kingdome on a fresh flame; and then none shall beat me off from this belief, That the Parliament sits to no other end and purpose, but to protect murder, and to councell Treason.

div.head: ART. XI.
div.p: I doe beleeve, That before 12. Suns surround the earth • globe, that there will be such a clashing in the Army, that the noise of it will give occasion either of the weale or woe of the whole Kingdome; in the mean space (to let England see her complexion in the glasse of time.) I am afraid (not making it an Article of my Beliefe) that though the King is at (a supposed) liberty, yet there is room enough in that little Le to be guilty of Royall murder; which heavens forbid.

div.head: ART. XII.
div.p: I doe beleeve, That every true Subject, faithfull to his principles, loyall to his Soveraigne, aad obedient to the Lawes, with a willing heart and chearfull spirit, may make this free and full profession, without breach of Charity or hurt to Conscience, still praying for the returne of his Majestie, with safety, freedome, and honor, the continuation of Parliaments (but not for Seven yeers) the purity of Religion, the establishing and exercise of wholsom Lawes, and the setling of Peace, love and Unity both amongst our selves, and all others our Christian brethren.
